com.link_intersystems.lang.reflect

Class Class2<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.link_intersystems.lang.reflect.Class2<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class Class2<T>
extends Object
implements Serializable
    An extension to the Class that encapsulates complex logic like finding an applicable method or constructor and handling generic types.

    Generic type handling

    Suppose the following hierarchy 

    
                             +-----------------+                               +-------------------+
                             |  AInterface<A>  |                               | BInterface<B, BB> |
                             +-----------------+                               +-------------------+
                                      ^                                                  ^
                                      |                                                  |
                 +-----------------------------------------+       +-------------------------------------------+
                 |  AClass<A> implements AInterface<Long>  |       | CInterface<C,CC> extends BInterface<CC,C> |
                 +-----------------------------------------+       +-------------------------------------------+
                                      ^                                                  ^
                                      |                                                  |
                +---------------------+--------------------------------------------------+
                |                                                                        |
 +------------------------------+          +-------------------------------------------------------------------+
 |BClass extends AClass<Integer>|          | CClass extends AClass<Float> implements CInterface<Byte, Boolean> |
 +------------------------------+          +-------------------------------------------------------------------+

    In the previous described hierarchy the following code's assertions will be true 

     Class2 aClass = Class2.forClass(AClass.class);
 Class2 bClass = Class2.forClass(BClass.class);
 Class2 cClass = Class2.forClass(CClass.class);

 TypeVariable<?> aClassTypeVariable = aClass.getTypeVariable("A");
 Type bBoundType = bClass.getBoundType(aClassTypeVariable);
 assertEqual(Integer.class, bBoundType);

 Type cBoundType = cClass.getBoundType(aClassTypeVariable);
 assertEqual(Float.class, cBoundType);

 // bounded types are also resolved in a complex hierarchy,
 // even if the bounded types got swapped in
 // the hierarchy like in CInterface<C,CC> extends BInterface<CC,C>
 Class2 bInterface = Class2.forClass(BInterface);
 TypeVariable<?> bInterfaceTypeVariable = bInterface.getTypeVariable("BB");
 cBoundType = cClass.getBoundType(bInterfaceTypeVariable);
 assertEqual(Byte.class, cBoundType);

    Since:
    1.0.0;
    Author:
    Ren√© Link [rene.link@link- intersystems.com]
    See Also:

      • getApplicableConstructor

        public Constructor2<T> getApplicableConstructor(AccessType[] accessTypes,
                                                Class<?>... invocationParameters)
        Identifies the Constructor2 of this Class2 that is applicable for the invocation parameters. Uses the same search algorithm as getApplicableMethod(String, AccessType[], Class...) . If the Class represented by this Class2 is an interface this method does never return a Constructor2 always null.
        Returns:
        the applicable constructor or null if no applicable constructor could be found.
        Since:
        1.0.0;

      • getApplicableConstructor

        public Constructor2<T> getApplicableConstructor(AccessType[] accessTypes,
                                                Object... invocationArguments)
        Identifies the Constructor2 of this Class2 that is applicable for the invocation parameters and AccessTypes. If this class represents an interface null is returned.
        Parameters:
        accessTypes - the AccessType that the selected constructor must have.
        Since:
        1.0.0;

        public Method2 getDeclaringMethod2(String name,
                                   Class<?>... parameterTypes)
                            throws NoSuchMethodException
        Returns the declaring method2 object using the same logic as Class.getDeclaredMethod(String, Class...).
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the method.
        parameterTypes - the exact parameter types that the declaring method must have.
        Returns:
        the Method2 that represents the declaring method with the name and Assert.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if no method matches the parameters.
        Since:
        1.0.0;

      • getApplicableMethod

        public Method2 getApplicableMethod(String name,
                                   Object... args)

      • getApplicableMethod

        public Method2 getApplicableMethod(String name,
                                   AccessType[] accessTypes,
                                   Class<?>... paramTypes)
        Identifies the Method2 of this Class2 that is applicable for the name and invocation parameters, including those methods declared by this class or interface and those inherited from superclasses and superinterfaces. Uses the search algorithm defined by the java language specification - 15.12.2.1 Identify Potentially Applicable Methods. 
          
        15.12.2.1 Identify Potentially Applicable Methods.
        
  A member method is potentially applicable to a method invocation if and only if all of
  the following are true:
  
          
  
        • The name of the member is identical to the name of the method in the method invocation.
          • 
  
        • The member is accessible (¬ß6.6) to the class or interface in which the method
 invocation appears.
          • 
  
        • The arity of the member is lesser or equal to the arity of the method invocation.
          • 
  
        • If the member is a variable arity method with arity n, the arity of the method
  invocation is greater or equal to n-1.
          • 
  
        • If the member is a fixed arity method with arity n, the arity of the method
  invocation is equal to n
          • 
  
        • If the method invocation includes explicit type parameters, and the member is a generic
  method, then the number of actual type parameters is equal to the number of formal type
  parameters.
          •
        Parameters:
        name - the method's name.
        paramTypes - the parameter classes.
        Returns:
        the applicable method or null if no applicable method exists in this class nor in it's superclasses.
        Since:
        1.0.0;

      • getDeclaredApplicableMethod

        public Method2 getDeclaredApplicableMethod(String name,
                                           AccessType[] accessTypes,
                                           Class<?>... paramTypes)
        Identifies the Method2 of this Class2 that is applicable for the name and invocation parameters, but excludes inherited methods. Uses the search algorithm defined by the java language specification - 15.12.2.1 Identify Potentially Applicable Methods. 
          
        15.12.2.1 Identify Potentially Applicable Methods.
        
  A member method is potentially applicable to a method invocation if and only if all of
  the following are true:
  
          
  
        • The name of the member is identical to the name of the method in the method invocation.
          • 
  
        • The member is accessible (¬ß6.6) to the class or interface in which the method
 invocation appears.
          • 
  
        • The arity of the member is lesser or equal to the arity of the method invocation.
          • 
  
        • If the member is a variable arity method with arity n, the arity of the method
  invocation is greater or equal to n-1.
          • 
  
        • If the member is a fixed arity method with arity n, the arity of the method
  invocation is equal to n
          • 
  
        • If the method invocation includes explicit type parameters, and the member is a generic
  method, then the number of actual type parameters is equal to the number of formal type
  parameters.
          •
        Parameters:
        name - the method's name.
        paramTypes - the parameter classes.
        Returns:
        the applicable method or null if no applicable method exists in this class.
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getApplicableMethod

        public Method2 getApplicableMethod(String name,
                                   AccessType[] accessTypes,
                                   Object... args)
        Same behavior as getApplicableMethod(String, AccessType[], Class...), but uses invocation parameter objects. E.g. finds a methods that is applicable to be invoked with the invocation parameter objects.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the method.
        args - the invocation parameters.
        Returns:
        the applicable method or null if no applicable method exists in this class nor in it's superclasses.
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getDeclaredApplicableMethod

        public Method2 getDeclaredApplicableMethod(String name,
                                           AccessType[] accessTypes,
                                           Object... args)
        Same behavior as getDeclaredApplicableMethod(String, AccessType[], Class...), but uses invocation parameter objects. Finds a methods that is applicable to be invoked with the invocation parameter objects.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the method.
        args - the invocation parameters.
        Returns:
        the applicable method or null if no applicable method exists in this class.
        Since:
        1.2.0;

        Returns:

        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getTypeVariable

        public TypeVariable<?> getTypeVariable(String typeVarName)
        Returns:
        the TypeVariable for the given name that is defined on this generic type or null if no TypeVariable is defined with that name. This method only looks at the current type represented by this generic object and not on super types.
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getBoundType

        public Type getBoundType(TypeVariable<?> typeVariable)
        Parameters:
        typeVariable - the TypeVariable to get the bounded type for.
        Returns:
        the type that is bound on this generic type for the given TypeVariable or null if the type is not bound on this generic's type. If the bound type is a generic type the raw type will be returned.
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getBoundClass

        public <C> Class<C> getBoundClass(String typeVarName)
        Convenience method that returns the bound class of the first type variable occurrence in the class's hierarchy. Every class in the hierarchy will be traversed. If a class doesn't define a type variable with the required name that class's interfaces gets traversed too. If also no interface has a type variable with the required name the next class in the hierarchy will be traversed.
        Returns:
        the class bound to this class's type variable with the typeVarName. Searches the class hierarchy for the first occurrence of a type variable with the given name.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no type variable definition could be found in this class's hierarchy.
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getBoundClass

        public <C> Class<C> getBoundClass(TypeVariable<?> typeVariable)
        Returns:
        the class that is bound on this generic type for the given TypeVariable or null if the type bound is not a Class. If the bound type resolved for the TypeVariable is itself a ( ParameterizedType ) the raw type will be returned.

      • getBoundInstance

        public <TI> TI getBoundInstance(TypeVariable<?> typeVariable,
                                Object... constructorArgs)
        Type Parameters:
        TI - the expected type so that clients must not cast.
        Parameters:
        typeVariable - the type variable that defines the class to be instantiated.
        constructorArgs - the arguments to use when constructing the bound type.
        Returns:
        an instance of the bound type defined by the typeVariable - constructing it with the constructorArgs. The right constructor is determined by the constructorArgs object's types.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - in case of an InstantiationException, IllegalAccessException or InvocationTargetException that arises when trying to instantiate the class bound to the type variable.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the type bound to the type variable is an interface or the constructor that is called to instantiate the class bound to the type variable itself throws an IllegalArgumentException or. The original exception is wrapped to provide more information.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Same as toString(String...) with parameter "java.lang".
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of this Class2;
        Since:
        1.0.0;

      • toString

        public String toString(String... wellKnownPackages)
        The string representation of a Class2.
        • Types are represented by their canonical name. If a type is a "well-known" type (all types in java.lang) the type's simple name is used. E.g. String - java.util.List.
          • Arrays are represented by their type and appended by []. E.g. int[] String[] java.beans.PropertyDescriptor[].
        Parameters:
        wellKnownPackages - packages that are "well known" will not be printed in the string representation. E.g. if java.lang is defined as well known the Class2 that represents a String class will be printed just as "String" and not java.lang.String.
        Returns:
        a string representation of this Class2;
        Since:
        1.0.0;

      • getClassLoader

        public ClassLoader getClassLoader()
        Nullsafe ClassLoader resolution. If this Class2 represents a system class the ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader() will be returned.
        Returns:
        the class loader of this Class2.
        Since:
        1.2.0;
